conclusion: Understanding the problem of two cars colliding after braking due to a siren warning.
The velocity-time graph shows car A starting at 25 m/s and car B at 15 m/s, both decreasing linearly to zero.
The x-axis is time in seconds, and the y-axis is velocity in meters per second.
Both cars are decelerating at a constant rate.
Deceleration of car A is calculated as -0.833 m/s².
Deceleration of car B is calculated as -0.6 m/s².
Collision occurs when the distance traveled by car A equals the distance traveled by car B plus the initial distance between them.
Both cars start braking at the same time and collide during the braking period.
At 20 seconds, both lines intersect, meaning both cars have the same velocity.
Need to find the time when the distance between them is zero.
Initial velocities and decelerations are defined for calculations.
Assumption that the initial distance between the cars is zero.
Distance traveled by car A is calculated as 25t - 0.4165t².
Distance traveled by car B is calculated as 15t - 0.3t².
Setting s_A = s_B to find collision time.
Solving for t gives t = 0 or t ≈ 85.88 seconds.
Car A stops at 30 seconds, and car B stops.
